Comment: Here is an interesting game between freddy and I.  Through White's 15th move, the moves were predetermined.  I was playing against freddy in another game and began discussing another one of my games that had just ended (http://gameknot.com/analyze-board.pl?bd=12254551&fb=1&rnd=0.7325155933749681).  I mentioned that I had blundered a piece in a game and that I eventually resigned as the game became "hopeless."  Freddy asked if I would like to replay that game from the point where I first blundered, only he would take Black (I was Black in the original game) and I would take White (essentially Freddy is spotting me a Knight).  I accepted for two reasons--I knew the game would be a learning experience and for a brief time, I had a material lead over freddy.  [freddy gets credit for naming this game]

Black goes with The Modern Defense.  As I annotate through move 15, I will take on Black's perspective because in the original game, I was Black.  After move 15, I will be annotating from White's perspective.
While there are a number of ways to go with The Modern, the moves of this game were relatively common thus far.

13...Nxe4.  In the original game, I was feeling good about myself.  I had attacked White's center, I was up a pawn, and I felt my development was adequate.
13...Nxe4.  In the original game, I was feeling good about myself.  I had attacked White's center, I was up a pawn, and I felt my development was adequate.
14. Qc2  In the original game, I over-focus on my development.  I do not pay attention to the fact that Ne4 is attacked twice but defended only once.  I castle to further my development.
15. Bxe4.  In the original game, as Black, I lost my Knight.  In this game, I am playing White, and it is freddy who has lost his Knight.
15. Bxe4.  In the original game, as Black, I lost my Knight.  In this game, I am playing White, and it is freddy who has lost his Knight.

15...Bxe4.  I asked freddy why he exchanged LSBs as he is behind in material.  He commented that d5 (my original move when I played Black) was probably best, but he wanted to escape the past game and enter into unknown territory.

My general plan was to develop my pieces and work slowly toward exchanging down into an endgame with a material lead.  I wanted to maintain initiative as well.  This never seems to happen when I play freddy--well not yet anyway.

I'm thinking that I should have moved Rab1 or Reb1 to seize the open file.  I seem to be playing to defensively, something that is easy to fall into when playing someone 600 rating pts better than you.

I went back and forth between Bd2 and Bb2.  I was concerned about Bb2 because it seemed like my B was just hanging out there.  As soon as I moved Bd2, freddy said I should have gone Bb2 and then he showed me why.
Bye-bye pawn. :(   But I'm still up a material point :)
